breakingChangesNotes:
Column Api

 - getAllColumns: Use `api.getColumns`
 - getPrimaryColumns: Use `api.getColumns`
 - getSecondaryColumns: Use `api.getPivotResultColumns`
 - setSecondaryColumns: Use `api.setPivotResultColumns`
 - getSecondaryPivotColumn: Use `api.getPivotResultColumn`

Grid API

- refreshServerSideStore: Use `refreshServerSide`
- getServerSideStoreState: use `getServerSideGroupLevelState`
- setProcessSecondaryColDef: Use `api.setGridOption('processPivotResultColGroupDef', newValue)` 
- setProcessSecondaryColGroupDef: Use `api.setGridOption('setProcessPivotResultColGroupDef', newValue)`
- setGetServerSideStoreParams: Use `api.setGridOption('getServerSideGroupLevelParams', newValue)``

GridOptions

- serverSideStoreType: Deprecated in favour of suppressServerSideInfiniteScroll. When false, Partial Store is used. When true, Full Store is used.
- serverSideSortingAlwaysResets: Use `serverSideSortAllLevels`
- serverSideFilteringAlwaysResets: Use `serverSideOnlyRefreshFilteredGroups`
- processSecondaryColDef: Use `processPivotResultColDef`
- processSecondaryColGroupDef: Use `processPivotResultColGroupDef`
- getServerSideStoreParams: Use `getServerSideGroupLevelParams`
- onRowDataChanged: No longer fired, use `onRowDataUpdated`

SSRM Interfaces 


- ServerSideGroupLevelParams.storeType: Deprecated in favour of suppressInfiniteScroll Partial -> suppressInfiniteScroll = false, Full -> suppressInfiniteScroll = true
- IsApplyServerSideTransactionParams.storeInfo: use IsApplyServerSideTransactionParams.groupLevelInfo instead
- LoadSuccessParams.storeInfo: Use LoadSuccessParams.groupLevelInfo instead
- IServerSideGetRowsParams.successCallback: Use `success` method instead with `LoadSuccessParams` params
- IServerSideGetRowsParams.failCallback: Use `fail` instead.


- interface ServerSideStoreParams: Use ServerSideGroupLevelParams
- interface GetServerSideStoreParamsParams: Use GetServerSideGroupLevelParamsParams
- interface RefreshStoreParams: Use RefreshServerSideParams
- interface ServerSideGroupState: Use ServerSideGroupLevelState

ExportParams 

- columnGroups: groups are exported by default.
- skipGroups: Use `skipRowGroups`
- skipHeader: Use `skipColumnHeaders`
- customFooter: Use `appendContent`
- customHeader: Use `prependContent`


- interfaces RangeSelection: Use CellRange
- interface AddRangeSelectionParams: Use CellRangeParams

React 

- rowDataChangeDetectionStrategy: Identity / reference equals always used

moreInformation:
Limited Workaround for Selecting Rows on Current Page

There is a limited workaround available for specific scenarios to select values on the current page when using SSRM with paging. 

It requires the following settings in gridOptions:
maxBlocksInCache:1,
rowBuffer needs to be equal to paginationPageSize
cacheBlockSize value needs to be a factor of paginationPageSize value, less than paginationPageSize value

1. Open https://plnkr.co/edit/cYQ8qCwSLYOpsdAM?open=main.js
2. Move to page 2
3. Click SELECT THIS PAGE button
4. Move to page 3
5. Click the GET SELECTED ROWS button
Actual & Expected: Console shows selected rows
6. Move to last page
7. Click the GET SELECTED ROWS button
Actual & Expected: Console shows selected rows
8. Move to first page
9. Click the GET SELECTED ROWS button
Actual & Expected: Console shows selected rows
10. Move to second page
Actual & Expected: Rows shown as selected
11. Click the GET SELECTED ROWS button
Actual & Expected: Console shows selected rows

moreInformation:
You can implement this by saving/restoring the vertical and horizontal scroll positions using internal API members (subject to change):
1. Open
Example (JS): https://plnkr.co/edit/STPMHNk8wW2gl6S4
Example (Angular): https://plnkr.co/edit/QrDOQiw4Zs2OuW11
2. Scroll the grid down
3. Scroll the grid right
4. Refresh the plunker preview using the small refresh button in the plunker preview pane (not the entire browser window)
Actual & Expected: Grid reloads, earlier scrollbar positions restored


Note in this sample the scroll position gets saved to local storage inside the onBodyScroll event handler. Also, onBodyScroll event handler gets called when the grid first initializes so we ignore the first call. The scroll positions get restored inside the firstDataRendered event handler which gets fired when the grid is rendered for the first time.

summary: [Row Grouping] In SSRM, sorting non-group columns shouldn't remove group column order when groupMaintainOrder=true
moreInformation:
This behaviour was originally also reported on CSRM. The observed behaviour is: 

Open: https://plnkr.co/edit/KhTKJjSYdr67KreA?open=main.js, note that group column is sorted DESC (descending)
Click the TASK column header cell to sort it

Observed:
1/ Tasks sorted but only within groups
2/ Row groups not reordered (earlier row order preserved)
3/ Sort indicator cleared from group columns (ASSIGNEE), group column removed from sortModel

Noted:

1/ This is virtually confusing as the group columns arent sorted anymore, but the previous sort order is preserved. 
2/ This also removes the group columns from the sort model, which prevents returning to the same row order later.

This is as expected because Group Order is not the same as sorting as per Kiril's comment below.

[Accessibility] Allow editable grid cells to be announced as editable
moreInformation:
Announcing cells as editable isn't standard behavior even in Excel. You can open NVDA and click a cell in Excel and note it's not announced as editable.
 
However, you can customize AG Grid to add the appropriate accessibility-related attributes to announce grid cells in editable columns as editable.
 
Please see this here:
1. Open
https://plnkr.co/edit/gFdUGcYFUqTlt172?open=main.js
2. Open NVDA
3. Click a cell in the ATHLETE column (not editable column)
Actual & Expected: Cell value announced, no "editable" announcement 
4. Press the RIGHT ARROW key to focus a cell in the AGE column (editable column)
Actual & Expected: Cell value announced with "editable" announcement 
 
In order to generate the announcement, we're using a custom cell editor for the editable columns which modifies the accessibility attribute (aria-description) of the parent cell. 
 
Please use the same approach to implement this in your project.

moreInformation:
You can implement this as follows - in the nodeClick event params you can access the data of the clicked chart marker. In the data object, you need to add a property to store the unique row ID value and return this unique row ID in the getRowId callback. Then, when a user clicks a chart marker, can then find the corresponding row using the getRowNode API method.

Please see this approach shown here (using the country property to store the unique row ID values):
https://plnkr.co/edit/REjlcQPHycA7TBlX

Click a chart marker to select the grid row that contains the data shown by this marker.

moreInformation: Accessibility scanners detect the fact that checkboxes inside set filter items aren't focusable as an accessibility failure. However, this is only based on static DOM analysis and isn't an actual failure because AG Grid implements its own custom keyboard navigation to toggle the checkbox when the user works with the set filter item. This is why this is will be flagged as an issue by accessibility tests but not be an issue in practice.

moreInformation:
In the meantime, to sort non-string values consistently when grouping and not grouping, define a comparator on the columnDef which parses the type of the value:
1. Open https://plnkr.co/edit/QLAE81VdKMKXzd16?open=main.js
2. Note order of rows
Actual & Expected: AGE values sorted as numbers (1,2,10,11)
3. Open the column menu, group by AGE column
4. Note order of row groups
Actual: Row group values sorted as strings (1,10,11,2)
Expected: Row group values sorted as numbers (1,2,10,11)

To sort non-string values consistently when pivoting, define a pivotComparator on the columnDef which parses the type of the value:
https://plnkr.co/edit/y6xZREq93X30T1c8?open=main.js
Pivot by AGE column and note the values are sorted numerically due to the pivotComparator.
breakingChangesNotes: Group values will no longer be typeless, and will be inferred from the first row when they were created.

moreInformation:
Workaround - provide event source via the grid context.
In sample below, note the setting of the grid context and reading this context in the onColumnVisible event to determine the source of the event (whether it's manual or in response to a call to applyColumnState).

Please follow the steps below for an illustration:
1. Open
https://plnkr.co/edit/q7Hpn9MyO2qe1Nlr
2. Open dev console
3. Click Toggle Price column button (edited) 

Actual & Expected; Message in dev console indicating that column visible was called in response to restoring state = false

4. Click Reset columns button

Feedback from Github (multiple items relating to product and docs)
[Layout & Styling] Allow removing the focused styling from the selected cell range when grid loses focus
moreInformation:
When the grid is using range selection and a cell range is selected, clicking outside of the grid displays the currently selected cell range in the grid with selected style. This behavior is correct as it allows you to add your external UI (buttons) outside of the grid to process the selected cell range in the grid. The cell range appears shaded in the grid and provides a visual indication to the user which cells will be affected by any externally triggered action. This is why when range selection is enabled the selected range remains visible when you the grid loses focus.

One of the ways to override this default behavior is to remove the selected range when the grid loses focus. You can implement this as follows:
https://plnkr.co/edit/faOPr1Ztmhc2kL5j

The sort comparator in the sample above sorts NaN values using the following order: nulls -> NaNs -> numbers -> characters. You can modify it to treat NaN values according to your specific requirements.

[Column Sizing] Allow automatic autosize of columns when vertically scrolling to take into account column values in newly loaded rows and when horizontally scrolling new columns into view
moreInformation:
The grid uses row virtualization by default, which doesnt load values until they are scrolled into view. This is why the column auto-size functionality only uses cell values already loaded by the grid. This is why if there are long cell values which aren't scrolled into view, they're not taken into account in the auto-size column width calculation.

However, you can implement this by adding user code to run the auto-size logic each time the user scrolls horizontally or vertically or when the rows in the grid change due to sort/filter/etc.

See this shown here:
1. Open
https://plnkr.co/edit/L1aimDpm4zA3N96Z?open=main.js
2. Scroll right
Actual & Expected: Displayed columns are auto-sized as soon as new rows are scrolled into view
3. Scroll down
Actual & Expected: Displayed columns are auto-sized as soon as new rows are scrolled into view
4. Click a column header to sort
Actual & Expected: Displayed columns are auto-sized as soon as new rows are scrolled into view

There is a workaround to use a custom date format, but to do so you will need to implement your own Date Component - https://ag-grid.com/angular-data-grid/component-date/ . There is an example shown on this page that uses the third-party flatpickr library, which allows for you to do this.

Here's a Plunker set up that way with a date format configured - https://plnkr.co/edit/Ja3l0EkYK9bOnLIe?open=app%2Fapp.component.ts. Note that you need to change both the dateFormatOoo in the locale text, as well as the dateFormat passed into the flatpickr component.

moreInformation:
The infinite row model is part of AG Grid Community and doesn't support dynamic/auto row height as per the row model feature comparison table:
https://www.ag-grid.com/javascript-data-grid/row-models/#row-model-comparisons

Support for dynamic/auto row height is supported by the server-side row model, which is part of AG Grid Enterprise as shown in our documentation here:
https://www.ag-grid.com/javascript-data-grid/server-side-model-row-height/ 

Please consider using AG Grid Enterprise to support dynamic row heights with the server-side row model instead.

moreInformation:
You can implement this when using server-side row model with infinite scrolling using the approach described below. 

If you have a block size of 200 and want to start loading the next block (with rows 200-400) as soon as the user is scrolling past row index 100, you need to set rowBuffer=100. This way when the user is at row 101, the grid is instantiating row 201, and as that's outside of the data for the current block 0-200, that forces a request for a new block of data (with data for rows 200-400).

See this implemented here:
Infinite row model - https://plnkr.co/edit/MR8mzfOAQkrGsS5s?preview
Server-side row model - https://plnkr.co/edit/gEa4EdlRbVN8cjmo

See the messages in the developer console indicating the second block of data is loaded much earlier as the user is scrolling, so the user doesn't see loading indicators unless they scroll really fast. If that's the case, just increase the value of cacheBlockSize to load larger chunks of data at a time to accommodate that.

This is caused by the fact that the pinned columns arent rendered in sequence with un-pinned columns. This is throwing off the screen readers who expect that elements that are visually adjacent are adjacent in the DOM structure.

summary: [Column Group] Allow hiding all columns in a column group through the column group itself, as opposed to all the individual child columns
moreInformation:
You can't set visibility explicitly on a group column - a group column is only shown if any of its child columns are visible. This is why you can't hide a column group directly. In order to hide it, you need to hide all its child columns instead. 

You can do this by calling columnApi.setColumnVisible(false) on the child columns or by applying column state.

Steps to illustrate:
0. Open
https://plnkr.co/edit/3f3x4NEznDsdVuIf?open=main.js
1. Group by COUNTRY column
2. Click SAVE STATE button
3. Click the button above grid to hide ATHLETE column
Actual & Expected: Group column hidden
4. Click RESTORE STATE button
Actual & Expected: Group column shown

When using row spanning and the rowspan > rowBuffer, scrolling beyond the rowBuffer hides the rowspan
moreInformation:
You can workaround this issue by setting the gridOptions rowBuffer property to a larger value to pre-render more rows to allow the row span to render correctly. The rowBuffer property is documented here:
https://www.ag-grid.com/javascript-data-grid/grid-options/#reference-miscellaneous-rowBuffer

By default rowBuffer is 20, so if you have row spans with more than 20 rows, that will cause the issue. 

You can fix this by setting the rowBuffer property to a value equal or bigger than the number of rows in the largest row span you have. For example, so if your biggest row span is 100 rows, set rowBuffer to 100 to resolve this as shown here:
https://plnkr.co/edit/LQnxgxum7Md2TWIp

Note that in this example the row span is correctly shown as you scroll down.

Please keep in mind that using a larger value for rowBuffer will increase the memory footprint, as it pre-renders a larger number of rows before they're scrolled into view.

moreInformation:
After setting the Column Definitions and initializing the AGGrid instance, the grid is briefly rendered with columns in the wrong position or with incorrect widths, before the saved column state is applied (via call to applyColumnState(...)). 

By setting gridOptions.suppressColumnMoveAnimation = true; before instantiating the agGrid instance and re-enabling it again after the call to .applyColumnState(...), on the 1st render of the grid the columns are immediately rendered with the correct width and in the correct position according to the applied columnState.

https://plnkr.co/edit/YbBvyGfCZlaZnHGz

In this sample the data gets loaded and exported to Excel without any sorting/filtering applied from the grid.

Warning: When using large amounts of data, note there will be a delay until all the data gets downloaded, and increased memory usage in the browser. Please test this carefully using the largest amount of data your grid needs to handle to ensure that the user experience is acceptable.

moreInformation:
== filterModel typing ==
We do not type gridApi.setFilterModel() as the filter can be a custom filter, for which we don't (can't) have typings for, so the model MUST be any. For specific filters we provide, then the interface needs to be referenced independently (eg use NumberFilterModel for Number Filter).

With regards the type (lessThan, greaterThan etc) again the application can provide custom types, which blocks us for making this an enum.

moreInformation:
You can use a workaround and implement this behavior and force new data to be retrieved each time. However, this workaround is only available when using AG Grid with server-side paging. 

Instead of setting maxBlocksInCache=1, you can purge the cache each time the current page changes:
https://plnkr.co/edit/dNBb2MM2v07fwrwx

This way you're using dynamic/auto row height and are purging the cache each time a new data block is loaded.

[Row Height] Allow navigating to row index (by calling ensureIndexVisible API method) and restoring scroll location to work with row auto height (or dynamic row height)
moreInformation:
The easiest way to resolve this is to suppress row virtualization. This means the grid will size all rows and will know how far down to scroll exactly to bring a specific row into view. However this only works for client-side row model and even then is only applicable when you have a small number of rows shown in the grid as you'd like to avoid a larger initial rendering time.

So unless you've suppressed row virtualization (and loaded all data from the server), the grid doesn't know how tall the rows are until it scrolls them into view and sizes them, at which point the row you scrolled into view (or scrolled to by calling ensureIndexVisible API) may be pushed out of view because the rows above it have larger height.

You can address this by calling the ensureIndexVisible method multiple times separated by a short delay:
(server-side row model) https://plnkr.co/edit/oQYrtvjxhIuYlklx?open=main.js

See examples below for client-side and server-side row models which display an overlay while the grid is scrolling, so the user doesn't see the multiple scrolls happening:
(server-side row model) https://plnkr.co/edit/jPlX00IiUt0a0brb?open=main.js
(client-side row model) https://plnkr.co/edit/2XNiZ4eNx5wT5gNk?open=main.js

The delay between the calls to ensureIndexVisible allows the auto-height computation logic to run for the visible rows to set their height. This approach then keeps calling the ensureIndexVisible method as many times as necessary until the scrolling settles, which means all rows have sized themselves and no more scrolling is necessary to bring the desired row into view.

Please adjust the delay between the calls to ensureIndexVisible based on the slowest machines you need to support. You'll need to increase the delay to support slower machines which would take longer to render the rows after each call to the ensureIndexVisible API method.
